articles.headline: How X Is Trying to Win Over Influencers
articles.snippet: Linda Yaccarino, the chief executive of the platform formerly known as Twitter, is relying on her TV industry ties to recruit established stars to the site.
articles.abstract: Linda Yaccarino, the chief executive of the platform formerly known as Twitter, is relying on her TV industry ties to recruit established stars to the site.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time Don Lemon sat down to film a TV segment in April, he perched on a stool in front of the glaring lights of a CNN studio. When he starts filming again after a nearly yearlong hiatus, Mr. Lemon will have a different backdrop — and he will be calling his own shots.

articles.headline: How Closely Does Iran Control Its Proxy Forces? It Depends.
articles.snippet: Tehran provides arms and support to an array of militant groups across the Mideast, but it does not call all the shots, experts say.
articles.abstract: Tehran provides arms and support to an array of militant groups across the Mideast, but it does not call all the shots, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iran projects its military power through dozens of armed groups across the Middle East, but how much does it control their actions?

articles.headline: Prosecutor in Trump Georgia Case Admits Relationship With Colleague
articles.snippet: But the prosecutor, Fani T. Willis, said her relationship with Nathan Wade did not begin until after she hired him and argued that it should not disqualify her.
articles.abstract: But the prosecutor, Fani T. Willis, said her relationship with Nathan Wade did not begin until after she hired him and argued that it should not disqualify her.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fani T. Willis, the district attorney prosecuting the Georgia election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump, acknowledged on Friday a “personal relationship” with a prosecutor she hired to manage the case but argued that it was not a reason to disqualify her or her office from it.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: The Soft Landing Is Global, but It’s Cushiest in America
articles.snippet: Economies all over the world are lowering inflation while avoiding serious recession — but growth in the United States stands out.
articles.abstract: Economies all over the world are lowering inflation while avoiding serious recession — but growth in the United States stands out.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world is starting 2024 on an optimistic economic note, as inflation fades globally and growth remains more resilient than many forecasters had expected. Yet one country stands out for its surprising strength: the United States.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Ana Swanson, Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: U.S. Conducts Retaliatory Strikes Against Iranian Proxies as War Deepens
articles.snippet: The strikes, in response to a drone attack that killed three U.S. soldiers in Jordan this week, were a sharp escalation of hostilities in the Middle East.
articles.abstract: The strikes, in response to a drone attack that killed three U.S. soldiers in Jordan this week, were a sharp escalation of hostilities in the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States on Friday carried out a series of military strikes against Iranian forces and the militias they support in seven sites in Syria and Iraq, marking a sharp escalation of the war in the Middle East that the Biden administration has for four months sought to avoid.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Cast as Criminals, America’s Librarians Rally to Their Own Defense
articles.snippet: As libraries become battlegrounds in the nation’s culture wars, their allies are fighting to preserve access to their collections and keep themselves out of jail, or worse.
articles.abstract: As libraries become battlegrounds in the nation’s culture wars, their allies are fighting to preserve access to their collections and keep themselves out of jail, or worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: During 12 years as a youth librarian in northern Idaho, Denise Neujahr read to and befriended children of many backgrounds. Devout or atheist, gay or straight, all were welcome until a November evening in 2021, when about two dozen teens arriving at the Post Falls library for a meeting of the “Rainbow Squad” encountered a commotion at the entrance.

articles.headline: Anxiety, Mood Swings and Sleepless Nights: Life Near a Bitcoin Mine
articles.snippet: Pushed by an advocacy group, Arkansas became the first state to shield noisy cryptocurrency operators from unhappy neighbors. A furious backlash has some lawmakers considering a statewide ban.
articles.abstract: Pushed by an advocacy group, Arkansas became the first state to shield noisy cryptocurrency operators from unhappy neighbors. A furious backlash has some lawmakers considering a statewide ban.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a sweltering July evening, the din from thousands of computers mining for Bitcoins pierced the night. Nearby, Matt Brown, a member of the Arkansas legislature, monitored the noise alongside a local magistrate.

articles.headline: A City Built on Steel Tries to Reverse Its Decline
articles.snippet: Gary, Ind., home of U.S. Steel’s largest mill, is seeking a fresh economic start under a new mayor determined to draw new businesses and residents.
articles.abstract: Gary, Ind., home of U.S. Steel’s largest mill, is seeking a fresh economic start under a new mayor determined to draw new businesses and residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gary, Ind., was once a symbol of American innovation. The home of U.S. Steel’s largest mill, Gary churned out the product that built America’s bridges, tunnels and skyscrapers. The city reaped the rewards, with a prosperous downtown and vibrant neighborhoods.
articles.byline: By Santul Nerkar and Akilah Townsend

articles.headline: How Much for Thin Mints? Some Girl Scouts Raise Cookie Prices.
articles.snippet: While an increase in cost in parts of the country may surprise some cookie buyers, “Girl Scouts are not immune to the rising costs of life,” one leader said.
articles.abstract: While an increase in cost in parts of the country may surprise some cookie buyers, “Girl Scouts are not immune to the rising costs of life,” one leader said.
articles.lead_paragraph: As if sticker shock in grocery stores hasn’t been enough, inflation has hit another consumer favorite: Girl Scout cookies.

articles.headline: U.S. and U.K. Launch Heavy Strikes on Houthi Sites in Yemen
articles.snippet: The airstrikes, meant to deter attacks on ships in the Red Sea, came one day after the United States struck at other Iran-backed militias in Iraq and Syria.
articles.abstract: The airstrikes, meant to deter attacks on ships in the Red Sea, came one day after the United States struck at other Iran-backed militias in Iraq and Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States and Britain carried out large-scale military strikes on Saturday against multiple sites in Yemen controlled by Houthi militants, according to a statement from the two countries and six allies, as the Biden administration continued its reprisal campaign in the Middle East targeting Iran-backed militias.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Fear and Ambition Propel Xi’s Nuclear Acceleration
articles.snippet: China’s leader built up a nuclear arsenal, steeling for a growing rivalry with the United States. Now China is exploring how to wield its newfound strength.
articles.abstract: China’s leader built up a nuclear arsenal, steeling for a growing rivalry with the United States. Now China is exploring how to wield its newfound strength.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nineteen days after taking power as China’s leader, Xi Jinping convened the generals overseeing the country’s nuclear missiles and issued a blunt demand. China had to be ready for possible confrontation with a formidable adversary, he said, signaling that he wanted a more potent nuclear capability to counter the threat.

articles.headline: After the Quake: One Turkish Family’s Struggle
articles.snippet: In the year since earthquakes devastated southern Turkey, the Karapirli family has struggled to heal, find a home and cope with a bottomless sense of loss.
articles.abstract: In the year since earthquakes devastated southern Turkey, the Karapirli family has struggled to heal, find a home and cope with a bottomless sense of loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: Finally, 106 days after the ambulances rushed their battered bodies to the hospital, the couple were cleared to leave.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Safak Timur and Emin Ozmen

articles.headline: What Does Being Sober Mean Today? For Many, Not Full Abstinence.
articles.snippet: More younger Americans are shunning alcohol while embracing cannabis, ketamine and psychedelics, shaking up the field of addiction medicine.
articles.abstract: More younger Americans are shunning alcohol while embracing cannabis, ketamine and psychedelics, shaking up the field of addiction medicine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mike Reed, a musician and Uber driver in Arizona, said he quit drinking alcohol more than a decade ago when his roommates got so fed up with his unruly behavior that they threatened to kick him out.

articles.headline: Nikki Haley’s ‘Rock’ Is Watching Her Campaign From a Distance
articles.snippet: Deployed to Djibouti, Maj. Michael Haley has missed the highs and lows of his wife’s pursuit of the White House. He is still a big presence in her campaign.
articles.abstract: Deployed to Djibouti, Maj. Michael Haley has missed the highs and lows of his wife’s pursuit of the White House. He is still a big presence in her campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Nikki Haley conceded her deflating third-place defeat in the Iowa caucuses this month, the first person she thanked was nearly 8,000 miles away.
articles.byline: By Ken Bensinger and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: N.F.L.’s Rapid Embrace of Gambling Creates Mixed Signals
articles.snippet: The league is pushing to popularize and benefit from sports betting while still trying to guard against the potential pitfalls for its players, employees and fans.
articles.abstract: The league is pushing to popularize and benefit from sports betting while still trying to guard against the potential pitfalls for its players, employees and fans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the next week, the National Football League’s players, coaches, fans and executives will gather for an event that was virtually unthinkable just 10 years ago: the Super Bowl in Las Vegas, the gambling capital of the United States.

articles.headline: Don’t Bet on This Former Vegas Mayor Being at the Super Bowl
articles.snippet: Oscar Goodman tried for years to lure pro sports to Las Vegas. Now that he’s out of office and the N.F.L.’s premier event has arrived, he has no need for the “Big Game.”
articles.abstract: Oscar Goodman tried for years to lure pro sports to Las Vegas. Now that he’s out of office and the N.F.L.’s premier event has arrived, he has no need for the “Big Game.”
articles.lead_paragraph: It was just after 4 p.m. on a recent weekday, and Oscar Goodman, the mob lawyer turned Las Vegas mayor turned civic cheerleader, was sipping perhaps his first Hizzoner of the day.

articles.headline: U.S. Strikes Iranian-Backed Targets for Third Day in a Row
articles.snippet: The attack on Houthi militants in Yemen came as Secretary of State Antony Blinken headed for the Mideast to try to defuse escalating tensions.
articles.abstract: The attack on Houthi militants in Yemen came as Secretary of State Antony Blinken headed for the Mideast to try to defuse escalating tensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States launched scores of strikes across the Middle East over the weekend as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken set out for the region to push forward negotiations to secure the release of Israelis still held hostage in Gaza and get more humanitarian aid into the battered enclave.
articles.byline: By Vivek Shankar, Charlie Savage and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Zelensky Hints at Major Shake-Up of Ukraine’s Government
articles.snippet: The president said a “reset” was needed to revive the struggling war effort, adding that his plans were “about the direction of the country’s leadership” and not just about replacing his top general.
articles.abstract: The president said a “reset” was needed to revive the struggling war effort, adding that his plans were “about the direction of the country’s leadership” and not just about replacing his top general.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that a broad overhaul of the country’s military and civilian leadership was needed to reboot the war effort against Russia, suggesting that a major shake-up of his government was imminent.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Why Are Americans Wary While the Economy Is Healthy? Look at Nevada.
articles.snippet: Economic shocks over two decades, combined with reliance on volatile casinos, have undermined confidence despite an economy that’s bustling.
articles.abstract: Economic shocks over two decades, combined with reliance on volatile casinos, have undermined confidence despite an economy that’s bustling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Toni Irizarry recognizes that the economy has improved. Compared with the first wave of the pandemic, when Las Vegas went dark, and joblessness soared to levels not seen since the Great Depression, these are days of relative normalcy.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Bridget Bennett

articles.headline: Big Companies Cashed In on Mississippi’s Water. Small Towns Paid the Price.
articles.snippet: They vowed to fix water woes and save cities millions. But a Times investigation found the deals racked up debt and left many worse off than before.
articles.abstract: They vowed to fix water woes and save cities millions. But a Times investigation found the deals racked up debt and left many worse off than before.
articles.lead_paragraph: In winter 2021, more than 150,000 people living in Jackson, Miss., were left without running water.
articles.byline: By Sarah Fowler and Rory Doyle

articles.headline: Many Israelis Want Netanyahu Out. But There Is No Simple Path to Do It.
articles.snippet: There is no clear mechanism to force early elections in Israel. But there are other ways to oust the Israeli prime minister.
articles.abstract: There is no clear mechanism to force early elections in Israel. But there are other ways to oust the Israeli prime minister.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is on his last legs, it is widely believed, and will be forced to relinquish his post once the war against Hamas in Gaza ends.

articles.headline: Why Is Big Tech Still Cutting Jobs?
articles.snippet: Profits are up and the economy is strong. But the tech industry faces two challenges — dealing with a frenetic work force expansion in the pandemic and building A.I.
articles.abstract: Profits are up and the economy is strong. But the tech industry faces two challenges — dealing with a frenetic work force expansion in the pandemic and building A.I.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a year of big layoffs, job cuts at the tech industry’s largest companies trickled into the first month of 2024.

articles.headline: Fake and Explicit Images of Taylor Swift Started on 4chan, Study Says
articles.snippet: The people on 4chan who created the images of Ms. Swift thought of it as a sort of game, the researchers said.
articles.abstract: The people on 4chan who created the images of Ms. Swift thought of it as a sort of game, the researchers said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Images of Taylor Swift that had been generated by artificial intelligence and had spread widely across social media in late January probably originated as part of a recurring challenge on one of the internet’s most notorious message boards, according to a new report.

articles.headline: Summer Has Long Stressed Electric Grids. Now Winter Does, Too.
articles.snippet: Electric utilities, which designed their system to meet peak demand in sizzling weather, are straining to keep up during the cold.
articles.abstract: Electric utilities, which designed their system to meet peak demand in sizzling weather, are straining to keep up during the cold.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, managers of electric grids feared that surging energy demand on hot summer days would force blackouts. Increasingly, they now have similar concerns about the coldest days of winter.
